User JSON Input Description¶

Input parameter description¶

Parameter

Data type

Units

Description

epoch

str

year, month, day, hour, month, seconds

Mission epoch (date and time) in UT1 Gregorian. Comma seperated values. Eg: '2017, 1, 15, 22, 30, 20.111'

duration

float

days

Length of mission in days. Eg: 0.25

constellation

constellation json object

Constellation specifications.

instrument

list instrument JSON object

Instrument specifications (please refer InstruPy documentation). A list of instruments is to be specified.

satellite

satellite JSON object

Satellite specifications

groundStations

groundStations JSON object

Ground station specifications.

grid

grid json object

Coverage grid specifications.

pointingOptions

pointingOptions JSON object

Set of pointing options.

propagator

propagator json object

Propagator related items.

Note that either :code:`grid` OR the :code:`pointingOptions` JSON object is to be defined, corresponding to grid-based coverage calculations or pointing-options based coverage caclulations.

Note

Whenever list of JSON objects is required, please specify as a list (i.e. within square brackets “[..]”) even in the case only one object is to be specified.

constellation JSON object¶

Constellation specifications. Two types of constellation are accepted: custom, Walkerdelta and should be indicated in the @type name, value pair.

  1. "@type":"custom"

A list of satellites is to be specified with each satellite orbit described by it’s corresponding Keplerian elements. The following fields are expected per satellite:

Expected parameters¶

Parameter

Data type

Units

Description

idn

str or int

Unique satellite identifier. The names of the output files are based on this field.

sma

float

kilometers

Length of the orbit semi-major axis

ecc

float

Orbit eccentricity

inc

float

degrees

Orbit inclination

raan

float

degrees

Orbit Right Ascension of Ascending Node

aop

float

degrees

Orbit Argument of Perigee

ta

float

degrees

Orbit True Anomaly

Example:

"constellation":{
     "@type": "Custom",
     "orbit":[{
         "idn": 11,
         "sma": 7078.137,
         "ecc": 0.0,
         "inc": 96.67657116,
         "raan": 327.55,
         "aop": 0,
         "ta": 0
     },
     {
         "idn": 12,
         "sma": 6878.137,
         "ecc": 0.0,
         "inc": 88.67657116,
         "raan": 127.55,
         "aop": 0,
         "ta": 0
     }]
 }

Note that the individual orbits are specified as a list (within square brackets) in the orbit name, value pair.

  1. "@type":"Walkerdelta"

Under this option the user can define parameters of a Walker Delta constellation (as given in SMAD 3rd ed.) and the corresponding satellite orbits shall be auto-generated. The identifier of the satellites is coded as follows: xy where x indicates the plane number and y indicates the satellite number within the orbital plane. The following fields are expected for the definition of the Walker Delta constellation:

Expected parameters¶

Parameter

Data type

Units

Description

numberSatellites

int

Total number of satellites in the constellation

numberPlanes

int

Number of orbital planes

relativeSpacing

int

Factor controlling the spacing between the satellites in the different planes (See SMAD 3rd ed Pg 194).

alt

float

kilometers

Orbit Altitude

ecc

float

Orbit eccentricity

inc

float

degrees

Orbit inclination

aop

float

degrees

Orbit Argument of Perigee

Example:

"constellation":{
     "@type": "Walkerdelta",
     "numberSatellites": 4,
     "numberPlanes": 2,
     "relativeSpacing":3,
     "inc":56,
     "alt": 700,
     "ecc": 0.0001,
     "aop": 0
 }

The satellites generated by use of the constellation object are all equipped with the list of instruments specified in the instrument JSON object.

satellite JSON object¶

The satellites in the mission can be specified directly as a list of orbit -> @type:"Custom" and list of instrument JSON objects. This allows for an heterogneous distribution of different instruments among the satellites in the mission.

Example:

"satellite":    [{
     "orbit": { "@id": 1,
                "sma": 6878.137,
                "ecc": 0.0,
                "inc": 96.67657116,
                "raan": 60,
                "aop": 0,
                "ta": 0},
     "instrument": [{ "@type": "Basic Sensor",
                      "@id": "pay1_1",
                      ...
                      ...
                     },
                     { "@type": "Basic Sensor",
                         "@id": "pay1_2",
                         ...
                         ...
                     }
                    ]
     },
     {
     "orbit": { "@id": 2,
                "sma": 6878.137,
                "ecc": 0.0,
                "inc": 96.67657116,
                "raan": 60,
                "aop": 0,
                "ta": 0},
     "instrument": [{ "@type": "Basic Sensor",
                      "@id": "pay2_1",
                      ...
                      ...
                     }
                    ]

groundStations JSON object¶

The ground station data can be specifed in two ways:

  1. stationInfo JSON object

Within the stationInfo JSOn field, a list of ground-stations can be specifyed. The required parameters for each region are:

Expected parameters¶

Parameter

Data type

Units

Description

@id

str

Unique ground-station identifier

name

str

degrees

(Optional) name of the ground-station

lat

float

degrees

Latitude

lon

float

degrees

Longitude

alt

float

km

(Optional) Altitude. Default is 0km.

minimumElevation

float

degrees

Minimum elevation beyond which the ground-station cane see the satellite.

 
"groundStations":{
     "stationInfo":[
         { "@id": "gs1",
           "name": "Tacos",
           "latitude": 1,
           "longitude": 1.5,
           "altitude": 0,
           "minimumElevation": 7
         },
         { "@id": "gs2",
             "name": "Hilly",
             "latitude": 89,
             "longitude": -10,
             "altitude": 20,
             "minimumElevation": 7
         }
     ]
 }

  1. gndStnFileName or gndStnFilePath

By means of a data file containing the ground station info. In case the gndStnFileName key, value pair is specified, the file has to be present in the user directory. Otherwise a gndStnFilePath key, value pair may be used to give the complete path to the data-file. An example of the data file (name: groundStations) is given below. The column headers need to be as indicated.

Example:

"groundStations":{
     "gndStnFileName":"groundStations"
 }

"groundStations":{
     "gndStnFilePath":"C:\workspace\groundStations"
 }
Example of the ground station data file.¶

index

name

lat[deg]

lon[deg]

alt[km]

minElevation[deg]

1

Svalbard

78.23

15.40

0

0

2

TrollSat

-72.01

2.53

10

5

grid JSON object¶

There are two ways to specify the grid:

  1. "@type":"autoGrid"

Within the autoGrid JSOn field, a list of regions can be specified. The required parameters for each region are:

Expected parameters¶

Parameter

Data type

Units

Description

@id

str

Unique region identifier

latUpper

float

degrees

Upper latitude in degrees

latLower

float

degrees

Lower latitude in degrees

lonUpper

float

degrees

Upper longitude in degrees

lonLower

float

degrees

Lower longitude in degrees

A file named as covGrid containing the grid points is created within the user directory.

In addition to the region specifications, optionally two more parameters can be specified, which control the resolution of the generated grid.

Expected parameters¶

Parameter

Data type

Units

Description

customGridRes

float

degrees

(Optional) Grid resolution. A warning is issued if the internal computed grid resolution is coarser than the user specified grid resolution.

customGridResFactor

float

(Optional) Custom grid-resolution factor used to determine the grid-resolution. (Default value is 0.9.)

Example:

"grid":{
     "@type": "autoGrid",
     "regions":[{
         "@id":1,
         "latUpper":20,
         "latLower":15,
         "lonUpper":75,
         "lonLower":0
     },
     {
         "@id":2,
         "latUpper":-30,
         "latLower":-35,
         "lonUpper":45,
         "lonLower":20
     }
     ],
     customGridResFactor = 0.5
 }

  1. "@type":"customGrid" option

In this option the user supplies the grid points in a data file. If the covGridFileName key, value pair is used, the file has to be present in the user directory. If the covGridFilePath key, value pair is used, the entire path to the file needs to be supplied.

Example:

"grid":{
     "@type": "customGrid",
     "covGridFileName": "covGridUSA"
 }

"grid":{
     "@type": "customGrid",
     "covGridFilePath": "C:\workspace\covGridUSA.csv"
 }

The datafile needs to be of CSV format as indicated in the example below. lat[deg] is the latitude in degrees, and lon[deg] is the longitude in degrees. The grid-points are referred by indices starting from 0.

Example of the coverage grid data file. :header:lat[deg],lon[deg]¶

9.9

20

9.9

20.1015

9.9

20.203

-49.1

21.9856

-49.1

22.1383

-49.1

22.291

-49.1

22.4438

-49.1

22.5965

-49.1

22.7493

-49.1

22.902

Note

Please specify latitudes in the range of -90 deg to +90 deg and longitudes in the range of -180 deg to +180 deg. Do NOT specify the longitudes in range of 0 deg to 360 deg.

pointingOptions JSON object¶

This JSON object contains specifications of the pointing-options to be used to calculate the coverage. It contains a list of JSON fields, with each field having a format as follows:

Expected parameters¶

Parameter

Data type

Units

Description

instrumentID

str

The instrument identifier to which the corresponding pointing-options data-file is to be used. Multiple IDs separated by commas are allowed.

referenceFrame

str

Currently only the NadirRefFrame is supported.

pntOptsFileName

str

Name of the data-file containing the set of pointing options. This file has to be present in the user-directory.

pntOptsFilePath

str

Path to the data-file containing the set of pointing options. (Specify pntOptsFilePath or pntOptsFileName)

Warning

In the case when the pointing-options approach is used for coverage calculations, the instrument identifier becomes a compulsory attribute of the Instrument JSON field, since it is needed to reference the pointing-options files.

Warning

The name of the data-file containing the pointing-options should not have any whitespaces. The pointing-otions indicated in the file are strictly indexed from 0 onwards.

Example:

"pointingOptions":[
    {
    "instrumentID": "sen1",
    "referenceFrame": "NadirRefFrame",
    "pntOptsFileName":"pOpts_sen1"
    },
    {
    "instrumentID": "sen2",
    "referenceFrame": "NadirRefFrame",
    "pntOptsFilePath":"C:\workspace\sen2_pOpts"
    },
 ],

Example of the data-file:

Euler (intrinsic) rotations with sequence 1,2,3 assumed, i.e. R = R3R2R1, with rotation matrix representing rotation of the coordinate system.
index,euler_angle1[deg],euler_angle2[deg],euler_angle3[deg]
0,0,0,0
1,0,20,0
2,0,-20,0

propagator JSON object¶

This JSON object contains items relating to the propagator.

Expected parameters¶

Parameter

Data type

Units

Description

customTimeStep

float

seconds

(Optional) Orbit propagation time-step. A warning is issued if the internal computed time-step is coarser than the user specified time-step.

customTimeResFactor

float

seconds

(Optional) Custom time-resolution factor used to determine the propagation time-step. (Default value is 0.25.)
